name: logic
content:
logic

noun
 OPAL W
 
/ˈlɒdʒɪk/
 
/ˈlɑːdʒɪk/
jump to other results
  1.  
    [uncountable] a way of thinking or explaining something
    • I fail to see the logic behind his argument.
    • The two parts of the plan were governed by the same logic.
    Extra Examples
    • I can't follow the logic of what you are saying.
    • In their faulty logic, this is a great injustice.
    • What kind of twisted logic is that?
    • You can't use the same logic in dealing with children.
    • They questioned the logic underlying his actions.
    • The music has its own inner logic.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • compelling
    • impeccable
    • inexorable
    • …
    verb + logic
    • accept
    • follow
    • see
    • …
    preposition
    • logic behind
    • logic in
    • logic of
    • …
    See full entry
  2.  
    [uncountable, singular] sensible reasons for doing something
    • Linking the proposals in a single package did have a certain logic.
    • a strategy based on sound commercial logic
    • logic to/in something There is no logic in any of their claims.
    Extra Examples
    • It's a stupid decision that completely defies logic.
    • There doesn't seem to be any logic in the move.
    • The plan had a simple logic to it.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • compelling
    • impeccable
    • inexorable
    • …
    verb + logic
    • accept
    • follow
    • see
    • …
    preposition
    • logic behind
    • logic in
    • logic of
    • …
    See full entry
  3.  
    [uncountable] (philosophy) the science of thinking about or explaining the reason for something using formal methods
    • the rules of logic
    • Philosophers use logic to prove their arguments.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • formal
    • mathematical
    • deductive
    • …
    verb + logic
    • apply
    • use
    See full entry
  4. [uncountable] (computing) a system or set of principles used in preparing a computer or electronic device to perform a particular taskTopics Computersc2
    5. Word Originlate Middle English: via Old French logique and late Latin logica from Greek logikē (tekhnē) ‘(art) of reason’, from logos ‘word, reason’.
See logic in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee logic in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: logic

name: -logic
content:
-logic

combining form
jump to other results
  1. ​-logical

name: fuzzy logic
content:
fuzzy logic

noun
 
/ˌfʌzi ˈlɒdʒɪk/
 
/ˌfʌzi ˈlɑːdʒɪk/
[uncountable] (computing)
jump to other results
  1. ​a type of logic with values other than 0 and 1 (for example, cold, warm and hot) so that computers and machines can more easily handle real-world applications
    • The fuzzy logic checks for the extent of dirt and grease, the amount of soap and water to add, the direction of spin, and so on.
See fuzzy logic in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: fuzzy logic

name: logic bomb
content:
logic bomb

noun
 
/ˈlɒdʒɪk bɒm/
 
/ˈlɑːdʒɪk bɑːm/
(computing)
jump to other results
  1. ​a set of instructions that are written into a computer in order to cause damage or to get secret information, and that will start operating when particular conditions exist
See logic bomb in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: logic bomb

name: logic gate
content:
logic gate

noun
 
/ˈlɒdʒɪk ɡeɪt/
 
/ˈlɑːdʒɪk ɡeɪt/
(also gate)
(computing)
jump to other results
  1. ​an electronic switch that reacts in one of two ways to data that is put into it. A computer performs operations by passing data through a very large number of logic gates.
See logic gate in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee logic gate in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: logic gate

name: logic circuit
content:
logic circuit

noun
 
/ˈlɒdʒɪk sɜːkɪt/
 
/ˈlɑːdʒɪk sɜːrkɪt/
 (computing)
jump to other results
  1. ​a series of logic gates that performs operations on data that is put into a computerTopics Computersc2
See logic circuit in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: logic circuit

name: gate
content:
gate

noun
 
 
/ɡeɪt/
 
/ɡeɪt/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. ​
    enlarge image
     
     [countable] a barrier like a door that is used to close an opening in a fence or a wall outside a building
    • the front/main gate
    • the back/side gate
    • an iron gate
    • to open/close/shut a gate
    • He pushed open the garden gate.
    • outside a gate Students were still standing outside the school gates.
    • at a gate A crowd gathered at the factory gates.
    • gate to something Someone was waiting by the gate to his house.
    see also lychgate, starting gate, toll gate, wicket gate
    Extra Examples
    • Don't forget to shut the gate when you leave.
    • The gate shut behind him.
    • The great gates of the abbey were shut fast.
    • The heavy gate swung open.
    • a set of ornamental gates
    • a wide driveway with double gates
    Topics Gardensa2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • front
    • main
    • entrance
    • …
    … of gates
    • set
    verb + gate
    • open
    • bar
    • close
    • …
    gate + verb
    • open
    • swing open
    • close
    • …
    preposition
    • through a/​the gate
    See full entry
  2. ​
     
     [countable] an opening that can be closed by a gate or gates
    • I was slightly nervous as I entered the gates.
    • through a gate We drove through the palace gates.
    Extra Examples
    • Go through the gate and continue down the track.
    • He led us through a gate into a little garden.
    • Hesitantly, he emerged from the gates of the prison.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • front
    • main
    • entrance
    • …
    … of gates
    • set
    verb + gate
    • open
    • bar
    • close
    • …
    gate + verb
    • open
    • swing open
    • close
    • …
    preposition
    • through a/​the gate
    See full entry
  3. ​
     
     [countable] a way out of an airport through which passengers go to get on their plane
    • Passengers for Paris should proceed to gate 8.
    • at a gate BA flight 726 to Paris is now boarding at gate 16.
    Wordfinder

    • baggage reclaim
    • board
    • check-in
    • gate
    • immigration
    • lounge
    • passport
    • security
    • terminal
    Topics Transport by aira2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective

    • main
    • entrance
    • …
    … of gates
    • set
    verb + gate
    • open
    • bar
    • close
    • …
    gate + verb
    • open
    • swing open
    • close
    • …
    preposition
    • through a/​the gate
    See full entry
  4. ​[countable] a barrier that is used to control the flow of water on a river or canal
    • a lock/sluice gate
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • front
    • main
    • entrance
    • …
    … of gates
    • set
    verb + gate
    • open
    • bar
    • close
    • …
    gate + verb
    • open
    • swing open
    • close
    • …
    preposition
    • through a/​the gate
    See full entry
  5. ​[countable] the number of people who attend a sports event
    • Tonight's game has attracted the largest gate of the season.
  6. ​
    (also gate money)
     [uncountable] the amount of money made by selling tickets for a sports event
    • Today's gate will be given to charity.
  7. ​
    -gate
     (forming nouns from the names of people or places; used especially in newspapers) a political scandal connected with the person or place mentioned
    Word OriginFrom Watergate, the scandal in the United States that brought about the resignation of President Nixon in 1974.
  8. ​
    (also logic gate)
     (computing) an electronic switch that reacts in one of two ways to data that is put into it. A computer performs operations by passing data through a very large number of gates.
    9. Word OriginOld English gæt, geat, plural gatu, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch gat ‘gap, hole, breach’.
Idioms
come, get, etc. out of the gate(s)
  1. ​(North American English, informal) to be successful from the beginning, especially in sport
    • The Grizzlies came out of the gate motivated, bursting to a 27–10 lead.
    • The team has struggled to get out of the gate this year.
(right) out of the gate(s)
  1. ​(North American English, informal) right from the beginning of a situation or an activity
    • The trouble began right out of the gate.
    • The Democrats had a clear advantage out of the gate.
See gate in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee gate in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
